keyTakeAways: Iceland has recorded its first confirmed wild mosquitoes, specifically of the Culiseta annulata species, discovered in Kiðafell, Kjós in western Iceland.
The discovery marks a significant shift from Iceland's long-standing status as mosquito-free due to extreme cold conditions.
The species Culiseta annulata is native to the Eastern Hemisphere and adapted to cold climates, allowing it to survive in sheltered environments during winter.
The origin of the mosquitoes is unknown, with theories including arrival via ships or containers.
This discovery may be linked to climate change, as warming temperatures could expand mosquito range, though experts remain cautious about direct attribution.
Iceland has already experienced record-breaking heat, increasing the possibility of mosquitoes establishing in the wild.
Experts such as Colin J. Carlson suggest that while climate change may have increased the likelihood of such a discovery, it is not yet clear if it was a direct cause.
Further monitoring is needed in spring to determine whether the species can survive winter and become established in Iceland.
The expansion of mosquito range due to climate change is a growing global concern, with mosquitoes thriving in warmer, wetter environments and posing health risks.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Iceland has officially confirmed its first wild mosquitoes, specifically the species Culiseta annulata, discovered in Kiðafell, Kjós in western Iceland. The discovery, made by resident Björn Hjaltason in October 2025 and verified by entomologist Matthías Alfreðsson, marks a significant ecological shift due to Iceland’s historically inhospitable cold climate. The species is adapted to cold conditions and may have arrived via ships or containers, with climate change potentially increasing the likelihood of future mosquito establishment. While experts note that warming temperatures may facilitate broader mosquito range expansion, it is not yet clear if climate change directly caused this event. Ongoing monitoring in spring is essential to determine if the mosquitoes can survive winter and establish permanently. This discovery underscores growing global concerns about climate change enabling disease-carrying insects to expand into previously uninhabited regions.
title: Iceland Just Found Its First Mosquitoes
